/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Vanuatu: Below is a partial list of populated places in Vanuatu.
/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Vanuatu: This is a list of islands of Vanuatu by province, largely from north to south, subdivided by archipelago when appropriate. Vanuatu is usually said to contain 83 islands.
/wiki/Provinces_of_Vanuatu: Vanuatu has been divided into six provinces since 1994. The names in English of all provinces are derived from the initial letters of their constituent islands:
/wiki/ICAO_airport_code: The ICAO (/ˌaɪˌkeɪˈoʊ/, eye-KAY-oh) airport code or location indicator is a four-letter code designating aerodromes around the world. These codes, as defined by the International Civil Aviation Organization and published in ICAO Document 7910: Location Indicators, are used by air traffic control and airline operations such as flight planning.
/wiki/IATA_airport_code: An IATA airport code, also known as an IATA location identifier, IATA station code or simply a location identifier, is a three-letter geocode designating many airports and metropolitan areas around the world, defined by the International Air Transport Association (IATA). The characters prominently displayed on baggage tags attached at airport check-in desks are an example of a way these codes are used.
/wiki/Anatom: Aneityum (also known as Anatom or Keamu) is the southernmost island of Vanuatu, in the province of Tafea.
/wiki/Inyeug: Inyeug Island is a small uninhabited island in Tafea Province of Vanuatu in the Pacific Ocean. "Inyeug" means "Small Island" in a local language. Inyueg is also called Mystery Island by the cruise ships that regularly visit the island.
/wiki/Tafea_Province: Tafea is the southernmost of the six provinces of Vanuatu.
/wiki/Anatom_Airport: Anatom Airport (IATA: AUY, ICAO: NVVA), also known as Aneityum Airport, is an airfield serving the island of Aneityum, in the Taféa province in Vanuatu. The airfield is actually located on the smaller Inyeug island.
/wiki/Aniwa_Island: Aniwa is a small island in the southernmost province of Tafea, Vanuatu.
/wiki/Aniwa_Airport: Aniwa Airport (IATA: AWD, ICAO: NVVB) is an airfield on the island of Aniwa, in the Taféa province in Vanuatu.
/wiki/Ambrym: Ambrym is a volcanic island in Malampa Province in the archipelago of Vanuatu.  Volcanic activity on the island includes lava lakes in two craters near the summit.
/wiki/Malampa_Province: Malampa is one of the six provinces of Vanuatu, located in the center of the country. It consists of three main islands: Malakula, Ambrym and Paama, and takes its name from the first syllable of their names. It includes a number of other islands – the small islands of Uripiv, Norsup, Rano, Wala, Atchin and Vao off the coast of Malakula, and the volcanic island of Lopevi (currently uninhabited). Also included are the Maskelynes Islands and some more small islands along the south coast of Malakula.
/wiki/Craig_Cove_Airport: Craig Cove Airport is an airport in Craig Cove on Ambrym Island in Vanuatu (IATA: CCV, ICAO: NVSF).
/wiki/Erromango: Erromango is the fourth largest island in the Vanuatu archipelago. With a land area of 891.9 square kilometres (344.4 sq mi) it is the largest island in Tafea Province, the southernmost of Vanuatu's six administrative regions.
/wiki/Dillon's_Bay_Airport: Dillon's Bay Airport (IATA: DLY, ICAO: NVVD) is an airfield near Dillon's Bay on the island of Erromango, in the Taféa province in Vanuatu.
/wiki/Emae: Emae is an island in the Shepherd Islands, Shefa, Vanuatu.
/wiki/Shepherd_Islands: The Shepherd Islands (coordinates 16°48′S 168°30′E﻿ / ﻿16.8°S 168.5°E﻿ / -16.8; 168.5Coordinates: 16°48′S 168°30′E﻿ / ﻿16.8°S 168.5°E﻿ / -16.8; 168.5) are a group of islands lying between the larger islands of Epi and Éfaté, in the Shefa province of Vanuatu. The aggregate land area is 88 square kilometres (34 square miles). They were named by Captain Cook after Anthony Shepherd, a British astronomer and friend of Cook.
/wiki/Shefa_Province: Shefa is one of the six provinces of Vanuatu, located in the center of the country and including the islands of Epi and Efate and the Shepherd Islands.
/wiki/Siwo_Airport: Aromai Airport is an airport in Siwo on Emae Island in Vanuatu (IATA: EAE, ICAO: NVSE).
/wiki/Futuna_Island,_Vanuatu: Futuna is an island in the Tafea province of Vanuatu. It is the easternmost island in the country.
/wiki/Futuna_Airport: Futuna Airport (IATA: FTA, ICAO: NVVF) is an airfield on the island of Futuna, in the Taféa province in Vanuatu.
/wiki/Gaua: Gaua (formerly known as Santa Maria Island) is the largest and second most populous of the Banks Islands in Torba Province of northern Vanuatu. It covers 342 km².
/wiki/Banks_Islands: The Banks Islands (in Bislama Bankis) are a group of islands in northern Vanuatu. Together with the Torres Islands to the northwest, they make up the northernmost province of Torba. The group lies about 40 km (25 mi) north of Maewo, and includes Gaua and Vanua Lava, two of the 13 largest islands in Vanuatu. In 2009, the islands supported a population of 8,533 on a land area of 780 km².
/wiki/Torba_Province: Torba (or TorBa) is the northernmost province of Vanuatu, consisting of the Banks Islands and the Torres Islands.
/wiki/Gaua_Airport: Gaua Airport (IATA: ZGU, ICAO: NVSQ) is an airport on the island of Gaua, one of the Banks Islands in the Torba province in Vanuatu.
/wiki/Ipota: Ipota is a village in the municipality of Jajce, Bosnia and Herzegovina.
/wiki/Ipota_Airport: Ipota Airport (IATA: IPA, ICAO: NVVI) is an airfield near Ipota on the island of Erromango, in the Taféa province in Vanuatu. It is one of two airfields in the island, the other being Dillon's Bay Airport in the west.
/wiki/Lamap: Lamap (former named Port Sandwich) is a village in Malampa Province on the Malekula island in Vanuatu.
/wiki/Malekula: Malakula Island, also spelled Malekula, is the second-largest island in the nation of Vanuatu, in the Pacific Ocean region of Melanesia.
/wiki/Malekoula_Airport: Malekoula Airport (IATA: LPM, ICAO: NVSL), also known as Lamap Airport, is an airfield near Lamap on the island of Malekoula, in the Malampa province in Vanuatu. It is one of two airfields on the island, the other being Norsup Airport in the north.
/wiki/Epi_(island): Epi (or Épi, Api; formerly known as Tasiko or Volcano Island) is an island in Shefa Province, Vanuatu, at the north end of the Shepherd Islands.
/wiki/Lamen_Bay_Airport: Lamen Bay Airport (IATA: LNB, ICAO: NVSM) is an airport in Lamen Bay on Epi, Vanuatu.
/wiki/Longana: Longana is a village located on the eastern part of Ambae island in Penama Province, Vanuatu.
/wiki/Aoba_Island: Ambae Island, also known as Aoba or Oba and formerly Leper's Island, is an island in the South Pacific island nation of Vanuatu, located near 15°30′S 167°30′E﻿ / ﻿15.500°S 167.500°E﻿ / -15.500; 167.500, approximately 165 miles (266 km) NNW of Vanuatu's capital city, Port Vila.
/wiki/Penama_Province: Penama is one of the six provinces of Vanuatu, located in the northeast of the country and consisting of three major islands:
/wiki/Longana_Airport: Longana Airport is an airport in Longana, Vanuatu (IATA: LOD, ICAO: NVSG).
/wiki/Pentecost_Island: Pentecost Island is one of the 83 islands that make up the South Pacific nation of Vanuatu.
/wiki/Lonorore_Airport: Lonorore Airport (IATA: LNE, ICAO: NVSO) or Lonoror (possibly from Ske lon or or "in the fences") is an airport on south-western Pentecost Island, Vanuatu, 3 km south of Baravet village.
/wiki/Luganville: Luganville is the second largest city in Vanuatu. Its population is 16,312.
/wiki/Espiritu_Santo: Espiritu Santo[a] (UK: /ɛˌspɪrɪtuː ˈsæntoʊ/, US: /- ˈsɑːntuː, - ˈsɑːntoʊ/; French: [ɛspiʁity sɑ̃to]) is the largest island in the nation of Vanuatu, with an area of 3,955.5 km2 (1,527.2 sq mi) and a population of around 40,000 according to the 2009 census.
/wiki/Sanma_Province:
Sanma is a province located in the Northern part of the nation of Vanuatu, occupying the nation's largest island, Espiritu Santo, which is located approximately 2,500 km northeast of Sydney, Australia.
Sanam 
The name Sanma is derived from the initial letters of the main islands of (Espiritu) SANto and MAlo.
/wiki/Santo-Pekoa_International_Airport: Santo-Pekoa International Airport is an airport in Luganville on Espiritu Santo in Vanuatu (IATA: SON, ICAO: NVSS). Airports Vanuatu Limited provides aviation services for the airport.
/wiki/Maewo: Maewo (local pronunciation: [ŋʷaewo]; formerly Aurora Island) is an island in Vanuatu in Penama province, 105 km to the east of Espiritu Santo.
/wiki/Maewo-Naone_Airport: Maewo-Naone Airport (IATA: MWF, ICAO: NVSN) is an airport on Maewo in Vanuatu.
/wiki/Mota_Lava: Mota Lava or Motalava (coordinates 13°42′S 167°39′E﻿ / ﻿13.7°S 167.65°E﻿ / -13.7; 167.65) is the fourth largest island in the Banks Islands of Vanuatu, after Gaua, Vanua Lava and Ureparapara, with an area of 24 km2 (9.3 sq mi).
/wiki/Mota_Lava_Airport: Mota Lava Airport (IATA: MTV, ICAO: NVSA) is an airport located on the island of Mota Lava, one of the Banks Islands in the Torba province in Vanuatu. Also known as Valua Airport, it is located on the eastern end of Motalava island, near the village of Aplow (formerly known as Valuwa).
/wiki/Norsup: Norsup is an island and village in the province of Malampa on Malakula Island in Vanuatu.
/wiki/Malekoula: Malakula Island, also spelled Malekula, is the second-largest island in the nation of Vanuatu, in the Pacific Ocean region of Melanesia.
/wiki/Norsup_Airport: Norsup Airport (IATA: NUS, ICAO: NVSP) is an airfield near Norsup on the island of Malakula, in the Malampa province in Vanuatu. It is one of three airfields on the island, the others being Lamap Airport and South West Bay in the south.
/wiki/Olpoi_Airport: Olpoi Airport (IATA: OLJ, ICAO: NVSZ), also known as North West Santo Airport, is an airport in Olpoi on Espiritu Santo, Vanuatu.
/wiki/Paama: Paama (Paama language: Voum) is a small island in the Malampa Province, Vanuatu.
/wiki/Paama_Airport: Paama Airport (IATA: PBJ, ICAO: NVSI) is an airport on Paama island, in the Malampa Province of Vanuatu.
/wiki/Port_Vila: Port Vila (French: Port-Vila), or simply Vila (English: /ˈviːlə/; French: Vila; Bislama: Vila [viˈla]), is the capital and largest city of Vanuatu and is on the island of Efate.
/wiki/Efate: Efate is an island in the Pacific Ocean which is part of the Shefa Province in Vanuatu. It is also known as Île Vate.
/wiki/Bauerfield_International_Airport: Bauerfield International Airport (IATA: VLI, ICAO: NVVV) is an airport located in Port Vila, Vanuatu. The airport is relatively small in size, but its runway has the capability and length to accept jets up to the Airbus A330. It serves as the hub for Vanuatu's flag carrier airline, Air Vanuatu.
/wiki/Quoin_Hill_Airport: Quoin Hill Airfield was an airfield in North Efate, in Vanuatu (IATA: UIQ, ICAO: NVVQ). The airfield was used during World War II but is no longer usable as an airstrip.
/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Vanuatu: This is a list of airports in Vanuatu, sorted by location.
